text-align: right;"><strong><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt;">. . .Accused-petitioners </span></em></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">The State</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">. . .Opposite party </span></em></strong></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 167(5) </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">It is pertinent to point out that the case is pending for investigation for about fifteen months. Section 167 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (briefly as the Code) provides the procedure when investigation cannot be completed in twenty four hours. The relevant provisions regarding granting of bail, when the investigation is not concluded within the stipulated period. <span style="mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">Section 167(5) provides that if the investigation is not concluded within one hundred and twenty days from the date of receipt of the information relating to the commission of the offence or the order of the Magistrate for such investigation. (a) the Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of such offence or making the order for investigation may, if the offence to which the investigation relates is not punishable with death, imprisonment for life or imprisonment exceeding ten years, release the accused on bail to the satisfaction of such Magistrate; and (b) the Court of Session may, if the offence to which the investigation relates is punishable with death, imprisonment for life or imprisonment exceeding ten years, release the accused on bail to the satisfaction of such Court; provided that if an accused is not released </span></span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold','serif'; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">on bail under this sub-section, the Magistrate</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-style: italic;"> or, as the case may be, the Court of Session shall record the reasons for it; </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">It find that no reason regarding applicability of the provisions of Section 167(5) of the Code has been assigned by the learned Judge in refusing bail of the petitioners. So, such findings of the learned Judge cannot be sustained in the eye of law.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Therefore, in view of the Provisions of section 167(5) of the Code the petitioners may be released on bail.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">     </span>. . . (11 and 13)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 498 </span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">According to the prosecution it is not the prima facie case against the petitioners but reasonable grounds for believing that they have been guilty which prohibits granting of bail. The onus is on the prosecution to disclose those reasonable grounds but the prosecution utterly failed to discharge its onus. I have carefully examined the data available in the case to find out whether reasonable ground exists to connect with the crime alleged, but I failed to discover any such ground which prohibits granting of bail of the petitioners. Both the petitioners were arrested in this case on 27-04-2013, about fifteen months they have been languishing in the custody for the allegations of committing offences which are absolutely bailable. We should bear in mind that it has </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold','serif'; letter-spacing: -.4pt;">been settled by our Apex Court that bail should</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;"> not be </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold','serif'; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">withheld as a punishment. In all these aforesaid</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;"> situations, I feel that the </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold','serif'; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">petitioners are entitled to be enlarged on bail.</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;"> Thus the Rule having merit succeeds.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">         </span>. . . (14 and 16)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mr. Yusuf Hossain Humayun, Senior Advocate with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mr. S.M. Rezaul Karim, Advocate and</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mr. M. Aminuddin, Advocate</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">…. For the accused-petitioners</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mr. Mamtajuddin Fakir, Additional Attorney General with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mrs. Sakila Rowshan, D.A.G. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mrs. Sharmina Haque, A.A.G. and</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Mr.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Md. Shorowardi, A.A.G..</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">. . . For the State-opposite party.</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><u><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong><u></u></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><u><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">Syed Md. Ziaul Karim, J: </span></u></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">Supplementary</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;"> Affidavit dated 21-07-2014 filed to-day do form part of the main petition. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">2.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">By this Rule, the petitioners seek bail.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">3.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">At the time of issuance of Rule both the petitioners were enlarged on ad-interim bail for a period of six months but due to some procedural facts they could not be released in time. Eventually the Miscellaneous case has been referred by the Hon’ble Appellate Division before this Court for disposal. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">4.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">The prosecution case put in a nutshell are that on 25-04-2013 at 00.45 hrs. S.I. Wali Asraf Khan of Savar Model Police Station, Dhaka as informant lodged a first information report( briefly as FIR) against the petitioner no.1 as accused no.6 along with five others alleging that accused nos.1 and 2 are the owners of " RANA PLAZA" a nine storied building situated at Savar Bazar Bus stand, of which 3<sup>rd</sup> -9<sup>th</sup> floors were being used as Garment factories of the other accused as tenants, Aminul Islam( accused no.3) as tenant of 3<sup>rd</sup>–4<sup>th floors</sup> operated his garment factories named New Wave Button and New Wave. Anisuzzaman (accused no.5) and David Mayor (accused no.4) as tenants of 5<sup>th</sup> – 6<sup>th</sup> floors operated their garment factories named Fantom Tec. Ltd. and Fantom Apparels Ltd. The petitioner no.1(accused no.6) as tenant of 7<sup>th</sup> to 8<sup>th</sup><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>floor operated his garment factories named Ether-Tex and New Wave Style. About 3000 workers and 200 staffs were employed in such factories. On 23-04-2013 at 9:30 a.m. some cracks were visible at different levels of the building. On panic some workers hurriedly got down and became wounded. In spite of such cracks on the following day i.e. on 24-04-2013, the owners of the garments and their officers compelled the workers to resume their duties. Consequently at 08.45 hrs. the total building collapsed and 203 workers/stuffs died at the spot and about 1000 were wounded. Having had heard the incident different law enforcers and NGO workers happened at the scene for their rescue. Some wounded were also shifted to local hospitals and clinics for treatment. By such incident total loss for Tk. Thirty five crore have been incurred. With these allegations the informant lodged the FIR which was recorded as Savar Police Station Case no.55 dated 25-04-2013 corresponding to G.R. no. 257 of 2013 under sections 337, 338, 304A, 427, 34 of the Penal Code(Later sections 323, 325, 326, 307, 304 of the Penal Code were added). </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">5.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">The case is still pending for investigation.</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;"> On 27-04-2013, both the petitioners were arrested in this case. Later they were taken to Police remand for consecutive two occasions. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">6.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">Having been repeated unsuccessful for bail in the Courts below, the petitioners moved this application and obtained the present Rule.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">7.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">The learned Advocates appearing for the petitioners support the Rule and submit that the petitioners were arrested on 27-04-2013 since then they are in custody and the case is still pending for investigation. They add that there is no specific allegation against the petitioner no.1 and the name of the petitioner no.2 does not appear in the FIR. By furnishing supplementary affidavit they submit that some of the suspected accused along with one FIR named accused( Abdul Khaleq) were enlarged on ad-interim bail, and the prayer for bail of the petitioners stand on the same footing with that of the other co-accused who were enlarged on bail. They lastly submit that under the aforesaid circumstances the petitioners may be enlarged on bail. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">8.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">The learned Additional Attorney General appearing on behalf of the State opposes the Rule and submits that it is a very sensational case. He adds that name and fame of Bangladesh depends on the activities of the petitioners. He lastly submits that the petitioner no.1 was the owner of a garment and he had the responsibility for safety and security of the workers but he failed to do so. Therefore, their bail should not be granted at this stage. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">9.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">            </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">In order to appreciate their submissions, I have gone through the record and given my anxious consideration to their submissions. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">10.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">On exploration of the materials on record, at a very outset I find that the offences as alleged as against the petitioners are under sections 337, 338, 304A, 427, 34 of the Penal Code. Although later sections 323, 325, 326, 307, 304 of the Penal Code were incorporated by the investigating authorities. The case is still pending for investigation and the applicability of the subsequent added sections have not yet been determined. So, till now I find that the FIR discloses the offences of former sections which are absolutely bailable offence. In bailable offence the person accused has the indefeasible right to grant of bail subject to satisfactory sureties being offered if necessary. With this regard reliance is being placed in the case of Meah Mahmud Ali Qasuri vs. The State 15 DLR 429 (SC). </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">11.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">It is pertinent to point out that the case is pending for investigation for about fifteen months. Section 167 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (briefly as the Code) provides the procedure when investigation cannot be completed in twenty four hours. The relevant provisions regarding granting of bail, when the investigation is not concluded within the stipulated period, reads as hereunder:</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 167(5) If the investigation is not concluded within one hundred and twenty days from the date of receipt of the information relating to the commission of the offence or the order of the Magistrate for such investigation.</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">(a)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">the Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of such offence or making the order for investigation may, if the offence to which the investigation relates is not punishable with death, imprisonment for life or imprisonment exceeding ten years, release the accused on bail to the satisfaction of such Magistrate; and</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">(b)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">the Court of Session may, if the offence to which the investigation relates is punishable with death, imprisonment for life or imprisonment exceeding ten years, release the accused on bail to the satisfaction of such Court; </span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Provided that if an accused is not released on bail under this sub-section, the Magistrate or, as the case may be, the Court of Session shall record the reasons for it;</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">12.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">It appears that the learned Judge consecutively refused the prayer for bail of the petitioners on the following observations : </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">″</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: MoinaNormal;">Cq¡ p¡i¡l l¡e¡ fÓ¡S¡ ¢h¢ôw d­p q¡S¡l q¡S¡l N¡­Ñj¾Vp LjÑ£l fË¡eq¡¢el OVe¡l HL¢V Q¡’mÉLl j¡jm¡z HC hSm¤p p¡j¡c A¡ce¡e l¡e¡ fÓ¡S¡l HL¢V N¡­jÑ¾Vp Hl j¡¢mL Hhw HC Bp¡j£l fËaÉr ®k¡Np¡S­p nË¢jL­cl ¢h¢iæ iui£¢a fËcnÑe L¢lu¡ L¡­S ®k¡Nc¡­e h¡dÉ L¢lu¡­Re h¢mu¡ </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ;">cywjk</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: MoinaNormal;"> fË¢a­hce qC­a ®cM¡ k¡uz</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">″</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">13.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Surprisingly, I find that no reason regarding applicability of the provisions of Section 167(5) of the Code has been assigned by the learned Judge in refusing bail of the petitioners. So, such findings of the learned Judge cannot be sustained in the eye of law.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Therefore, in view of the Provisions of section 167(5) of the Code the petitioners may be released on bail. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">14.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">According to the prosecution it is not the prima facie case against the petitioners but reasonable grounds for believing that they have been guilty which prohibits granting of bail. The onus is on the prosecution to disclose those reasonable grounds but the prosecution utterly failed to discharge its onus. I have carefully examined the data available in the case to find out whether reasonable ground exists to connect with the crime alleged, but I failed to discover any such ground which prohibits granting of bail of the petitioners.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">15.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Moreso, although the name of the petitioner no.1 appears in the FIR but I do not find any specific overtact involving him with the lynching of unfortunate workers and causing wounds to others. In respect of petitioner no.2, I failed to discover any allegation as alleged by the prosecution against him, even his name do not appear in the FIR. I have meticulously examined, the allegations made in FIR, Police forwarding report and the reports after remand but from there also, I failed to extract any material ground for believing that they have been guilty which prohibits granting bail. It is to be mentioned that meanwhile, FIR named accused Abdul Khaleq and other suspected accused namely Alam Mia, Md. Entemam Hossian, Mohammad Ali Khan, Md. Rokibul Hasan Rashel, Md. Abdul Hasan, Alhaj Md. Refat ullah and Sree Anil Das were enlarged on ad-interim bail by the different benches of this Division in different Miscellaneous cases. Although, subsequently the order of granting ad-interim bail of suspected accused Alam Mia was stayed by the Hon’ble<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Appellate Division. Therefore, I find that there is no material to discriminate the case of the petitioners from those of the co-accused who have been enlarged on bail earlier.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">16.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">It is very significant to me that both the petitioners were arrested in this case on 27-04-2013, about fifteen months they are languishing in the custody for the allegations of committing offences which are absolutely bailable. We should bear in mind that it has been settled by our Apex Court that bail should not be withheld as a punishment. In all these aforesaid situations, I feel that the petitioners are entitled to be enlarged on bail. Thus the Rule having merit succeeds.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">17.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">In view of foregoing narrative the Rule is made absolute. Let the petitioners (1) Bazlus Samad Adnan and (2) Mahmudur Rahman Tapash, be released on bail on furnishing bail bond to the satisfaction of Chief Judicial Magistrate, Dhaka. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">18.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">The learned Judge of the Court below is at liberty to cancel the bail of the petitioners if they misuse the privilege of bail in any manner whatsoever.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">19.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Office is directed to communicate the order at once.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Vrinda; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Ed. </span></strong></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" style="mso-footnote-id: ftn1;" title=""><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt;">Criminal </span></strong></a><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 11.0pt;">Miscellaneous Case No. 1630 of 2014</span></strong></p></div></div></div></div>
8	<h2 class="blog_entry-title"> Md. Abu Siddique Vs.  D. M. Habibur Rahman and other, (Md. Moinul Islam Chowdhury, J.)	   </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Case No:</b> Civil Revision No. 1896 of 2016 </p><p><b>Judge:</b>  Md. Moinul Islam Chowdhury, J</p><p><b>Court:</b> High Court Division,</p><p><b>Advocate:</b> Mr. Sheikh Muhammed Serajul Islam, Advocate,  Mr. Mahfujur Rahman Roman with Mr. M. Nahiyan Ibn Subhan, Advocates,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2018(2) LNJ  	 </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2018</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Md. Abu Siddique</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  D. M. Habibur Rahman and others </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-06-02</p><!DOCTYPE html><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"> </p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">HIGH COURT DIVISION</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">(CIVIL REVISIONAL JURISDICTION)</span></strong></p><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="MsoNormalTable" style="margin-left: 5.4pt; border-collapse: collapse; width: 201px;"><tbody><tr style="mso-yfti-irow: 0; mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;"><td style="width: 94.625px; padding: 0in 5.4pt;" valign="top"><p class="MsoHeading8" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in -1.4pt 6.0pt -5.4pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold',serif; letter-spacing: -.3pt; font-style: normal; mso-bidi-font-style: italic;">Md. mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">}</span></p></td><td style="width: 74.625px; padding: 0in 5.4pt;"><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;"> Abu Siddique</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 10.0pt;">. . . Petitioner</span></em></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt;">D. M. Habibur Rahman and others </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt;">... Opposite parties </span></em></strong></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.25pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ; color: white; mso-color-alt: windowtext;">gymwjg weevn I ZvjvK (wbeÜb) wewagvjv, 2009</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ;">wewa 13</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 110%;">A person cannot be a Nika Registrar for more than one Union Parishad but the present petitioner has been a Nika Register for two unions which is not permissible under the above new law. The settled principle in this regard is that everyone must be abide by the law introduced for any purpose and the present petitioner cannot get any benefit which the prevailing law does not permit.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">       </span>. . .(12)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt;">Order 7, Rule 11(d)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ;">gymwjg weevn I ZvjvK (wbeÜb) wewagvjv, 2009</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: SutonnyBanglaMJ;">wewa 13</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt;">A suit cannot be allowed to continue if the suit is barred by any law under the provision of Order 7 Rule 11(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure. In the present case therefore the suit is barred by law as the present plaintiff petitioner claimed a relief in the year of 2013 for injunction and for allowing him to function as Nika Registrar </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold',serif; letter-spacing: -.3pt;">of Palerchar in contravention to the<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>provision</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt;"> of law. . . . (12)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Mr. Sheikh Muhammed Serajul Islam, Advocate</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">. . . For the Petitioner </span></em></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Mr. Mahfujur Rahman Roman with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Mr. M. Nahiyan Ibn Subhan, Advocates</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">. . . For the Opposite Party No. 1</span></em></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><u><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Md. Moinul Islam Chowdhury</span></u></strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">, J:</span></u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;"> At the instance of the present plaintiff-opposite party-petitioner, Md. Abu Siddique, a leave was granted and this Rule has been issued calling upon the opposite party No. 1 to show cause as to why the judgment and order dated 28.10.2015 passed by the learned Additional District Judge, Shariatpur, in Civil Revision No. 13 of 2014 allowing the aforesaid revision and thereby reversing the judgment and order dated 30.04.2014 passed by learned Assistant Judge, Jajira, Shariatpur in Title Suit No. 128 of 2013 rejecting the application under Order VII, Rule 11(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure, should not be set aside. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 105%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">2.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 105%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The relevant facts for disposal of this Rule, <em>inter-alia</em>, are that the present petitioner as the plaintiff filed the Title Suit No. 128 of 2013 in the Court of learned Assistant Judge, Jajira, Shariatpur for a decree for permanent injunction to restrain the opposite party from appointing a Nika Registrar and also for a declaration to allow him to continue as a Nika Registgrar of Palerchar Union, Police Station-Jajira, Shariatpur. The plaint contains that the present plaintiff petitioner was appointed as a Nika Registrar for the Unions of Bilashpur, Kundarchar and Palerchar by the Ministry of Law and Parliamentary Affairs of the People Republic of Bangladesh on 18.08.1998, which was confirmed by the District Nika Registrar, Shariatpur on 02.09.1998. While he has been performing his duties Kunderchar Union went under river Padma by way of river erosion and the peoples of the said union moved away. The petitioner thereafter filed Writ Petition No. 4545 of 2003 in this court where a direction was given to issue permanent license for two unions namely Bilashpur and Palerchar. On 31.01.2013 a letter was issued by the defendant No. 6, Senior Assistant Secretary, Ministry of Law directing the sub-registrar of Jajira to appoint the defendant No.7, the present opposite party No. 1 as the Nika Registrar for the Union of palerchar as per the provisions of law published by a Gazette notification dated 10.08.2009. The plaintiff filed the suit challenging the said appointment.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">3.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The suit has been contested by the present opposite party No. 1, D. M. Habibur Rahman as the defendant No. 7 by filing a written statement and denying the statement made in the plaint and contending that the defendants (the authority) properly appointed Nika Registrar to the present opposite Party No. 1 for the Union of Palercar under the provisions of law. The present opposite party No. 1 also filed an application under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure for rejecting the plaint as the suit was barred by law.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">4.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">After hearing the parties the learned trial court rejected the application by his order dated 30.04.2014. Being aggrieved the present opposite party No. 1, as the applicant filed the Civil Revision No. 13 of 2014 in the court of learned District Judge, which was heard by the learned Additional District Judge, Shariatpur on transfer who by his judgment and order dated 28.10.2015 allowed the revision by setting aside the order passed by the learned trial court. This revisional application has been filed under Section 115(4) of the Code of Civil Procedure challenging the legality of the said order and a leave was granted and this Rule was issued thereupon. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">5.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Mr. Sheikh Muhammed Serijul Islam, the learned Advocate, appearing for the petitioner submits that it is clear from the plaint that the suit is not barred by any law but the court below failed to evaluate the same, thus, committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">6.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The learned Advocate also submits that the present petitioner filed the Writ Petition No. 4545 of 2003 which was partly made absolute directing to appoint the petitioner in two union parishads under Police Station- Jajira but the appointment of the present opposite party No. 1 by the Ministry of Law and Parliamentary Affairs has been violation of the direction given by this court and the suit should be allowed to dispose of on merit instead of by rejecting the plaint, therefore, the learned trial court after considering the pleadings rejected the application but the learned revisional court below committed an error of law by allowing the application filed under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Procedure, as such, this court should interfere for the ends of justice and the Rule should be made absolute.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">7.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The Rule has been opposed by the present opposite party No. 1.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">8.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Mr. Mahfujur Rahman Roman, the learned Advocate, appearing along with the learned Advocate Mr. M. Nahiyan Ibn Subhan, appearing for the opposite party No. 1, submits that the learned trial court rejected the application filed by the present opposite party under Order 7<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Rule<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>11 of the Code of Civil Procedure on the basis of the direction of Writ Petition which was passed in the year of 2005 but without considering the subsequent enforcement of law in the year of 2009, therefore, came to a wrongful conclusion. However, the learned<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>revisional court below after considering the prevailing law came to a lawful conclusion to allow the revision by setting aside the judgment and order passed by the learned trial court below, as such, this court should not interfere upon the judgment and order passed by the revisional court below and the Rule should be discharged.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">9.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The learned Advocate also submits that the present petitioner was appointed by the concern authority in the year of 1998 for three unions but after the enforcement of Rule 13 (Umo) of “</span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">j¤p¢mj ¢hh¡q J a¡m¡L (¢ehåe) ¢h¢dj¡m¡, 2009</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">” a person cannot be a Nika Registrar in more than one union parishad therefore the judgment and order in the Writ Petition in the year of 2005 became inoperative by the subsequent introduction of new law in the year of 2009 thus the Rule should be discharged.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">10.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Considering the above submissions made by the learned Advocates appearing for the respective parties and also considering the revisional application filed under Section 115 (4) of the Code of Civil Procedure, in particular, the impugned judgment and order passed by the revisional court below, it appears to me, that the present petitioner as the plaintiff filed a suit for permanent injunction restraining the Government opposite parties from appointing the present opposite party No.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>1 and also for a declaration permitting the present petitioner to continue functioning as the Nika Registrar for two unions namely Bilashpur and Palerchar under Police Station-Jajira, District-Shariatpur. The present opposite party No. 1, D.M. Habibur Rahman contested the suit by filing a written statement and also by filing an application under Order 7 Rule 11 of the Cod of Civil Procedure contending that the suit was barred by the law.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 107%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 107%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">11.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 107%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">In the above given factual aspects in this case, this court has to take a decision as to whether the suit filed by the present petitioner was actually barred by law or not. In order to take a decision in this matter I have carefully examined the available documents in the revisional application. I found that the suit was filed by the present petitioner claiming injunction and also seeking<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>a relief to continue function as Nika Registrar for two unions namely Bilashpur and Palerchar as per his appointment in the year of 1998. In this regard, this court seemed to have directed to give a permanent appointment to the petitioner in the said two unions, however, the court has also given liberty to the concern authority to appoint as per the provision of law. While the petitioner has been performing his function as Nika Registrar the law changed by introducing “</span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">j¤p¢mj ¢hh¡q J a¡m¡L (¢ehåe) ¢h¢dj¡m¡, 2009</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 107%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">” and it was introduced under the authority given under<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Section 14 of the Muslim Marriages and divorces (Registration) Act, 1974 (Act No. LII of 1974). The said Bidhemala contains Rule 13, which reads as follows:</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">“</span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; mso-ansi-language: EN;">13z A¢d­®rœz- HC ¢h¢dj¡m¡l Ad£e fËcš ¢eL¡qÚ ®l¢SÖY~Ê¡­­®ll m¡C­®p­¾p k¡q¡ ¢LR¤C b¡L¥L e¡ ®Le, HLSe ¢eL¡qÚ ®l¢SøÊÊ¡l­®L ¢ejÀh¢ZÑa Hm¡L¡l SeÉ m¡C­®p¾p fË¡ce Ll¡ k¡C­®h, kb¡x-</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 63.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; letter-spacing: -.4pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(L) ¢p¢V L­®fÑ¡®­ln®­el ®r®­œ, HL¢V<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Ju¡XÑ;</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 63.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; letter-spacing: -.4pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(M) "L' ®nËZ£l ®­f±lpi¡l ®r­®œ, c¤C¢V Ju¡XÑ;</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 63.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; letter-spacing: -.4pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(N) "M' ®nËe£l ®f±lpi¡l ®r­®œ, ¢ae¢V<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Ju¡XÑ;</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 63.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; letter-spacing: -.4pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(O) "N' ®nËZ£l ®f±lpi¡l ®r®­œ pjNË Hm¡L¡;</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 63.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal; mso-bidi-font-family: AdarshaLipiNormal; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">(P) CE¢eue f¢loc Hm¡L¡l ®r®­œ HL¢V CE¢euez</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">”</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">12.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">From the above provisions of law for Nika Registrar, a person cannot be a Nika Registrar for more than one union parishad but the present petitioner has been a Nika Register for two unions which is not permissible under the above new law. The settled principle in this regard is that everyone must be abide by the law introduced for any purpose and the present petitioner cannot get any benefit which the prevailing law does not permit. Accordingly, the petitioner lost his relief given by this court in the Writ Petition by the introduction of subsequent law in the year of 2009. A suit cannot be allowed to continue if the suit is barred by any law under the provision of Order 7 Rule 11(d) of the Code of Civil Procedure. In the present case therefore the suit is barred by law as the present plaintiff petitioner claimed a relief in the year of 2013for injunction and for allowing him to function as Nika Registrar of Palerchar in contravention to the<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>provision of law, as such, I consider that the suit should not be allowed<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>to continue any further as it is barred by law.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">13.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.2pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The learned trial court came to a wrongful</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;"> conclusion only on the directions given by this </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">court in a Writ Petition in the year of 2005 and <span style="letter-spacing: .4pt;">the learned trial court failed to consider the </span></span><span style="font-size: 11pt;">prevailing law applicable in the suit therefore committed an error of law, however, the learned revisional court considered the relevant facts in this case and the applicable law, therefore, came to a lawful conclusion to allow the revisional application by setting aside the judgment and order of the trial court. I am therefore not inclined to interfere into the judgment and order passed by the learned revisional courts below.</span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">14.<span style="font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">          </span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -.3pt; mso-ansi-language: EN;">Accordingly, I do not find merit in the Rule.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;">15.<span style="font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">In the result, the Rule is discharged. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;">16.<span style="font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">In view of the above discussion the present opposite party No. 1, D. M Habibur Rahman, son of D.M. Abu Sayeed shall function as the Nika Registrar of the Palerchar union parishad, under Police Station- Jajira, District-Shariatpur as per the appointment given on 31.01.2013 by the Senior Assistant Secretary, Ministry of Law by the present opposite party No. 6. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN;">17.<span style="font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">However it appears to this court that the union parishad of Bilashpur has been seriously effected by river erosion wherein the present petitioner, Md. Abu Siddique, son of late Md. A. Karim lost his enough opportunities of his function as Nika Registrar therefore the present opposite party Nos. 5, 6 and 7 may consider his  area  to function in an adjacent union in the event of any vacancy in future because of the fact of erosion most of the areas of Bilashpur union parishad.   </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">18.<span style="font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The interim order of stay granted at the time of issuance of the Rule upon the operation of the judgment and order dated 28.10.2015 passed by the learned Additional District Judge, Shariatpur in Civil Revision No. 13 of 2014 is hereby recall and vacated. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">19.<span style="font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; font-weight: normal; font-stretch: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-family: 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">The Section is directed to communicate this judgment and order to the court concern immediately.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-ansi-language: EN;">         Ed.  </span></strong></p><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><!--[endif]--><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><a href="file:///H:/article/18%20may%20aug/Issue___August__18/Issue%20__August__18(2)__C.%20R.%201896%20of%2016_Md.%20Moinul%20Islam%20Chowdhury,%20J.__1.doc#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" style="mso-footnote-id: ftn1;" title=""><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">Civil Revision No. </span></strong></a><strong><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">1896 of 2016</span></strong></p></div></div></div></div>
9	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">A. B. Bank Limited Vs. M/S Khan Enterprise and others, 2016(1) LNJ 26</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Case No:</b> First Appeal No. 192 of 2011 </p><p><b>Judge:</b>  Md. Iqbal Kabir,</p><p><b>Court:</b> High Court Division,,</p><p><b>Advocate:</b> Mr. Md. Nazmul Karim,Ms. Afroza Nazneen Akhter,,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2016(1) LNJ 26</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2016</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  A. B. Bank Limited</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  M/S Khan Enterprise and others</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Artha Rin, </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2015-06-22</p><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:16px"><strong>HIGH COURT DIVISION</strong><br/><strong>(CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION)</strong><br/> </span></div><table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="height:172px; width:374px"><tbody><tr><td style="width: 141px; text-align: right;"><strong>A.K.M. Asaduzzaman, J<br/>			And<br/>			Md. Iqbal Kabir, J<br/>			 <br/>			Judgment on<br/>			22.06.2015</strong></td><td style="width: 21px; text-align: justify;"> </td><td style="width: 125px; text-align: justify;"><div style="text-align: left;">A. B. Bank Limited</div><div style="text-align: right;"><strong><em>. . . Plaintiff/ Appellant </em></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">-<strong>Versus</strong>-</div><div style="text-align: left;">M/S Khan Enterprise and others</div><div style="text-align: right;"><strong><em>. . .Defendants/ Respondents</em></strong></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div style="clear: both; text-align: justify;"> </div><div style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Artha Rin Adalat Ain (VIII of 2003) </strong><br/><strong>Section 12(1)(2)(3)</strong><br/><strong>The Bank need/ exhaust the procedure laid </strong><strong>down under section 12(1) (2) (3) of the aforesaid</strong><strong> Ain before filing the suit. If plaintiff Bank does not follow the above procedure then the procedure also laid down in the section 12(6) and (7) of the said Ain will come into operation. . . . (16)</strong><br/> <br/><strong>Artha Rin Adalat Ain (VIII of 2003) </strong><br/><strong>Section 57</strong><br/><strong>Although it has proved that due to the State Emergency the damage has been taken place and the defendant suffered a huge loss but in such a situation there is no provision in the Artho Rin Adalat Ain to remit any interest. . . .(17)</strong><br/> <br/><strong>Artha Rin Adalat Ain (VIII of 2003) </strong><br/><strong>Section 50</strong><br/><strong>The legislature has given clear mandate enabling the plaintiff Bank to claim interest forming part of the principal amount as per the agreed contract of loan. In this case we have found that the court has exercised his inherent power, though this court has no jurisdiction to do so or entrusted any power to waive any interest accrued. In this enactment there is a specific provision to recover the default loan and interest. The court has to follow the procedure laid down therein; it cannot overlook the provision laid down there. . . . (19)</strong><br/> </div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 80px;"><strong>Mr. Najmul Karim, Advocate</strong></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 120px;"><em>…For the plaintiff-appellant.</em></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 80px;"><strong>Ms. Afroza Nazneen Akhter, Advocate</strong></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 120px;"><em>…For the Defendant –Respondent No.1.</em></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 80px;"><br/><strong>First Appeal No. 192 of 2011<br/> </strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:20px"><strong><u>JUDGMENT</u></strong></span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size:16px"><strong><u>Md. Iqbal Kabir, J:</u></strong></span><br/> <br/>This appeal has been presented, at the instance of the Plaintiff/Appellant against the judgment and decree dated 31.03.2011 passed by the Judge of the Artho Rin Adalat, Chittagong in Artho Rin Suit No. 33 of 2010.<br/><br/>The facts relevant for disposal of the appeal are that the plaintiff is a Bank and it has Banking business. On the other hand defendant-respondent No. 1 is a business   Enterprise and the defendant No. 2 is the owner of the said business and defendant No. 3 is the guarantor who deposited the mortgage property as collateral security against the loan.<br/><br/>The plaintiff sanctioned Tk. 14,10,00,000/- in favour of the defendants’ respondents against L/C and TR facilities as per the application dated 20-02-06. The plaintiff after considering the application allowed the same on 06-03-06. Defendant No. 2 and 3 understood the condition laid down in the sanction letter issued by the Bank  and which along with interest charges at agreed rate stood the claim of the suit. Against the aforesaid loan the defendant No. 2 executed various charge documents and deposited the same to the Bank. The land described in the schedule-1 and title deed described in schedule-2 deposited as collateral security by the defendant No. 3. In support of the mortgage the defendant No.3 on 21-03-06 executed a registered mortgage deed being No.966 and a Power of Attorney. Thereafter, on 12-03-08 the defendant applied to adjust the liability against the loan and the plaintiff Bank also agreed the same and on 02-04-08 issued a consent letter. However, the defendant failed to adjust the liability as a result the plaintiff Bank cancelled installment facility vide letter dated 02-07-09.  The plaintiff issued several remainder letters to pay the loan amount against which on 24-12-09 defendant No. 2 issued a cheque being No. 0245076 amount of Tk. 15,75,36,960/ in favour of the plaintiff that is AB Bank Limited, Export Processing Zone Branch, Chittagong. The said defendant also assured that if the cheque be placed for encashment the money would be paid. Subsequently the cheque was deposited but, it was dishonored as a result the plaintiff through his lawyer issued legal notice and finally filed a Case under section 138 of the Negotiable Instrument Act. As per the regular assessment against the account under L/C and TR facilities defendant failed to adjust the liability and the plaintiff  is entitled to recover loan through legal process and hence this suit.<br/><br/>The suit was contested by the defendants by filing written statement, denying all material assertion as set out in the plaint contending, inter alia, that the defendants with good reputation doing their business and they have good relation with the Bank and others. Under L/C and TR facilities defendant No. 2 imported 3000 Mt sugar on behalf of the defendant No. 1. They  have already made a payment of Tk. 1,41,00,000/- as 10% margin and after selling 800 MT sugar paid Tk. 4,04,04,400/-  but remaining amount of Tk. 8,64,56,000/- was unpaid. During Emergency period on 1.11.2007 a criminal case was lodged against the defendant No. 2 under section 25(1) of the Special Powers Act-1974 as a result the said sugar has been damaged causing huge loss to the defendant and thereby he was not in a position to repay the loan. However, to recover the said loss the defendant has taken initiative against the government. As such the defendant prays to remit the interest and for an adjustment of the loan amount vide three monthly installments spread over 20 years.<br/><br/>The learned Judge of the trial court framed 8 issues including 4 additional issues and examined one witnesses on behalf of the plaintiff and one witness on behalf of the defendants and by the impugned judgment decreed the suit in part.<br/><br/>Being aggrieved by the impugned judgment and decree the plaintiff appellant preferred the instant Appeal.<br/>Mr. Najmul Karim the learned advocate appearing on behalf of the appellant submits that trial Court erred in law in passing the impugned judgment and decree. He submits that the Artho Rin Adalat Ain does not allow the Court to remit the interest upon invoking jurisdiction under section 57 of this Act. He submits that section 18 of this Act do not allow the defendant to claim set-off or counter claim. Accordingly the borrower defendant is barred to include set-off or counter claim in the written statement. As a result the Court has no scope and jurisdiction to entertain any counter claim and thereby set-off any amount from the claim of any suit. He further submits that Artho Rin Adalat Ain has been created by special enactment only for recovery of defaulted loan. It has no power to adjudicate any other matters. Since defendant has taken the loan and in his testimony acknowledged the entire loan facilities and as such the trial Court has no scope to pass a partial decree.<br/><br/>He further submits that in view of section 50 of this Act, Court has no jurisdiction to reduce or remit any interest which has lawfully imposed against any loan. He submits that appellant is entitled to recover the loan through legal process and as such the judgment and decree is liable to be modified and a decree may be passed in full for the entire claim of the plaintiff.<br/><br/>Ms. Afroza Najneen Akhter learned Advocate appearing for the defendants submits that the suit is premature as because without complying the provision laid down under section 12 of the Artho Rin Adalot Ain, the Bank cannot file the suit, if file it would be premature and the trial court has rightly held that the suit is premature. She further submits that since the imported goods were under the custody of the plaintiff  and it was retained as pledge therefore the plaintiff  had to comply the procedure as laid down under section 12 of the Artho Rin Adalot Ain before filing a suit. She further submits that the imported Sugar was in the custody of the Bank as a result the Bank is responsible to sell it out before filing the suit. She further submits the plaintiff without disclosing the entire fact filed this suit which is also a violation of the provision of section 8 (Ga) of the said Act. Trial Court committed gross illegality in decreeing the suit without considering the above provision of law.<br/><br/>In reply the learned Advocate  for the appellant  has taken us to the plaint where it has clearly been stated that  “বাদীর সর্বাত্মক প্রচেষ্টা স্বত্বেও বিবাদীগন ঋণের টাকা আদায় না করায় এবং বন্ধকী সম্পত্তি পত্রিকায় নিলাম বিজ্ঞপ্তির মাধ্যমে বিক্রী না হওয়ায় বাদীকে আদালতের আশ্রয় গ্রহন করিতে হইল। বিবাদীগন বাদীর পাওনা টাকার জন্য আইনতঃ দায়ি হন।"<strong> A</strong>part from that in reply to the contention of the plaint, the defendant  in their written statement admitted that they took loan and some portion of loan amount has been repaid but due to the criminal case the alleged goods were damaged and they suffered huge loss. For which the government is responsible, and they have taken initiative against the government.<br/><br/>Plaintiff clearly speak that  the plaintiff has complied the provision and procedure laid down under section 12 of the said Act before filing of the suit .The document (Ext-10-10/a) that is a letter of Agreement wherein the defendant acknowledged plaintiffs right to cancel any or all the loan(s) of credit at anytime with or without prior notice to the defendant and defendant also undertake to pay you on demand all outstanding balances together with accrued interest and charges,” clearly speaks about the position of the defendant in the loan proceedings.<br/><br/>General Letter of Trust Receipt dated 06-03-06 (Ext 3/d) shows that the defendant also agreed by saying that “ It is also expressly agreed that so long as any goods of which you have allowed us to take delivery, but for which we have not paid, remain in our possession or under our control, you hold a lien on the same and are at liberty, at our expense, if you think fit to do so to re-take possession of the same without any notice or reference to our consent, from us, and to remove the same or any part thereof from the place where they have been stored to any other place you may choose and place the same under the care of any one you may select and to dispose of them by sale or otherwise as you may think necessary.” and further said “ We quite understand and agree that the handing to us of any shipping Document or Documents as above mentioned is entirely at your option and does not in any way alter or affect our personal liability or your rights under any other security or documents (s) you may hold.” From the above documents defendant has acknowledged his rights and responsibilities in the loan proceedings.<br/>He further submits that the plaintiff is not responsible to sell out the goods and the document will further shows that the goods were not in possession of the plaintiff and as per the procedure of hypothetical mortgage the bank will keep the documents not the goods. In fact the goods were under the custody of the defendant. The letter written by M/S Khan Enterprise dated 20.07.2008 (Ext-A) to the plaintiff will affirm the said contention.<br/><br/>He further submits that the defendant also prayed to re-schedule the loan amount and accordingly it was made. Even after that the defendant failed to do so. The above submission and document shows that the plaintiff has complied the provision of law and defendant is a defaulter and responsible to pay the entire amount of loan including the interest.     <br/> <br/>We have gone through the evidences on record, heard the learned Advocate for the parties and examined the relevant law, facts and circumstances.<br/><br/>Section 12 of the অর্থ ঋণ আদালত আইন, ২০০৩ (২০০৩ সনের ৮ নং আইন) speaks that:</div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;"><br/>১২। (১) উপ- ধারা (২) এর বিধান সাপেক্ষে, কোন আর্থিক প্রতিষ্ঠান, উহার নিজ দখল বা নিয়ন্ত্রতে থাকা বিবাদীর কোন সম্পত্তি যাহা পণ বা বন্ধক (lien or pledge)  রাখিয়া  ঋণ প্রদান করা হইয়াছে, এবং যাহা বিক্রয় করিবার আইনগত অধিকার বাদীষ রহিয়াছে বা বাদীকে অর্পণ করা হইয়াছে, উহা বিক্রয় না করিয়া এবং বিক্রয়লব্ধ  অর্থ ঋণ পরিশোধ  বাবদ সমন্বয় না করিয়া, অর্থ ঋণ আদালতে কোন মামলা দায়ের করিবে না।<br/><br/>(২) উপ-ধারা (১) এর বিধান সত্ত্বেও , কোন আর্থিক প্রতিষ্ঠান নিজ দখল বা নিয়ন্ত্রণে থাকা পণ বা বন্ধকী সম্পত্তি বিক্রয় না করিয়া মামলা দায়ের করিসে অনতিবিলমেব উক্ত সম্পত্তি পূর্ব- বর্ণিত মতে বিক্রয় করিয়া বিক্রয়লব্ধ অর্থ  ঋণের সহিত সমন্বয় করিবে এবং বিষয়টি আদালতকে লিখিতভাবে অবহিত করিবে।<br/><br/>(৩)
