Mamunur Rashid,Mr. Md. Noor-Us- Sadik,,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2016(1) LNJ 320</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2016</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Agrani Bank Ltd.</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  Messers Calico Cotton Mills Ltd. and others</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Civil Law, </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2016-1-21</p><div style="text-align: center;"><br/><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>HIGH COURT DIVISION</strong><br/><strong>(CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION)</strong><br/> </span></div><table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="height:178px; width:428px"><tbody><tr><td style="height: 136px; width: 227px; text-align: justify;"><div style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong>Sheikh Abdul Awal, J</strong><br/><strong>And</strong><br/><strong>Shahidul Karim, J.</strong><br/>			 <br/><strong>Judgment on</strong><br/><strong>21.01.2016</strong></span></div></td><td style="height: 136px; width: 36px; text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size:14px"> </span></td><td style="height: 136px; width: 202px; text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size:14px">Agrani Bank Ltd., Abdul Hamid Road Branch, Pabna</span><div style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong><em>. . . Plaintiff-Appellant</em></strong></span></div><span style="font-size:14px">-Versus-<br/>			Messers Calico Cotton Mills Ltd., Rajapur, Pabna and others</span><div style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-size:14px"><strong><em>. . . Defendant-Respondents</em></strong></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div style="clear: both; text-align: justify;"> </div><div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size:14px"> <br/><strong>Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</strong><br/><strong>Section 34</strong><br/><strong>The Court is empowered to grant interest from the date of the suit to the date of the decree and then on the full amount which includes the amount claimed on the date of the suit and the interest thereon granted by the Court for the aforesaid period. Further, this section provides for award of interest on the aggregate sum till the date of realization or an earlier date. It also transpires that the decree holder does not have any statutory right to get interest automatically.   Therefore, we find no difficulty whatever in holding that the grant or award of interest pendent lite is purely a matter of statutory power wherein the discretion of the Court is absolute.         . . .(20)</strong><br/> <br/>Mr. Md. Mamunur Rashid, Advocate<br/><strong><em>. . . For the appellant.</em></strong><br/>Mr. Habibul Islam Bhuiyan with<br/>Mr. Md. Noor-Us- Sadik, Advocates<br/><strong><em>. . . For the respondent No.5.</em></strong><br/> <br/><strong>First Appeal No. 5 of 2004</strong><br/> </span></div><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:20px"><strong>JUDGMENT</strong></span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size:14px"> <br/><strong><u>Sheikh Abdul Awal, J:</u></strong><br/> <br/><strong>1.</strong> This First Appeal at the instance of plaintiff- Agrani Bank is directed against the impugned judgment and decree dated 7.5.2003 (decree signed on 12.5.2003) passed by the learned Joint District Judge and Artha Rin  Adalat, Pabna in Artha Rin Mortgage Suit No.43 of 1996 decreeing the suit in-part.<br/> <br/><strong>2.</strong> Material facts of the case, briefly, are that the appellant, Agrani Bank Ltd. (Abdul Hamid Road Branch, Pabna) as plaintiff instituted the aforesaid Artha Rin Mortgage Suit No.43 of 1996 in the Court of Joint District Judge and Artha Rin Adalat, Pabna claiming an amount of Tk. 16,90,54,541.55 with interest against the defendant-respondents.<br/> <br/><strong>3.</strong> Plaintiff’s case in short is that  the defendant No.1, company was registered on 11.11.67 by the joint stock company  and thereafter started production of cotton on 9.11.68. After liberation the defendant company  was nationalized  on 26.03.1972 by the Govt. of Bangladesh and its management was entrusted with Bangladesh Textile Mills Corporation,  who availed loan from bank to run the mill. Pursuant to the policy decision of the Government the defendant company owing Calico Textile Mills, which was denationalized and its management was returned to its original sponsors and shareholders and the Government retained certain percentage shares of the defendant No.1, Company.   In the process of denationalization a tripartite agreement was executed between the Government of Bangladesh and the original sponsors of the defendant company and shareholders and the plaintiff bank. Loan in the name of BTMC amounting to TK. 5.17 crore as on 03.07.88 was transferred to Agrani Bank as per tripartite agreement dated 27.05.1988 executed by BTMC, defendant Mill and Bank. The Managing Director of Calico Cotton Mills under took to pay BTMC’s transferred liability on 24.05.1988  (exhibit-8) and thereafter, the defendant Mill further under took in writing to pay BTMC’s liability vide letter dated 15.04.1992 (exhibit-9). The plaintiff bank in not getting loan amount with interest   as per terms of loan sectioned letter served a   legal notice on 17.04.1996 claiming to repay outstanding loan of TK. 1,10,16,572.00 in CC (Pledge), TK. 1,60,58,457.83 in CC (hypo) &amp; BTMC’s transferred liability of TK. 12,81,92,866.00 totaling TK. 15,52,67,894.83 as on 31.03.1996   and thereafter, the defendant Calico Cotton Mill’s Chairman &amp; Director replied to the legal notice on 26.04.1996 (Exhibit-12) admitting the claim of the bank but on various pretext they did not come forward to adjust the loan liabilities and hence, the suit.<br/> <br/><strong>4.</strong> The defendant-respondents duly appeared in the suit and filed two sets of written statements taking the general pleas of maintainability of the suit, absence of cause of action and of being barred by limitation, bad for defect of parties. The claim of the plaintiff is false and without any basis and as such, the suit is liable to be dismissed.<br/> <br/><strong>5.</strong> At the trial the plaintiff side examined only one witness and the defendant side in all examined two witnesses and both the parties exhibited some documents to prove their respective cases.<br/> <br/><strong>6.</strong> The learned Joint District Judge and Artha Rin Adalat after hearing the parties and on considering the evidence and materials on record decreed the suit in-part by the impugned judgment and decree dated 7.5.2003.<br/> <br/><strong>7.</strong> Being aggrieved and dissatisfied with the aforesaid judgment and decree dated 7.5.2003 the plaintiff-Agrani Bank Limited filed this appeal.<br/> <br/><strong>8.</strong> Mr. Md. Mamunur Rashid, the learned Advocate appearing on behalf of the plaintiff-appellant-bank in the course of his argument after placing the impugned judgment and decree,  the evidence of PW-1, DW-1 and DW-2 and other materials on record including the tripartite agreement (Ext.7) submits that the Artha Rin Adalat erred in law in decreeing the suit in-part without properly considering the facts and circumstance of the case and the case made out by the plaintiff-bank that the liability of loan during the period of management of BTMC was transferred to Agrani Bank as per tripartite agreement (Ext.7) and everything was stated in the tripartite agreement which was admitted in evidence and it is on record that on 5.7.1988 the loan transferee  branch of the bank was informed that total liability of  Tk. 5,17,03,151.37 which was transferred through tripartite agreement and interest was charged up-to 03.07.1988. As per section 50 Artharin Adalat Ain-2003 no court can disallow interest which is to be calculated from the date of granting loan up-to the date of filing suit and as per section 50(2) of the Ain the Court is bound to grant pendente lite simple interest @ 12% p.a. from the dated of judgment to till realization. He further submits that the learned trial Judge had misunderstood and misappreciated the evidence on record and misjudged the issues in the suit and thereby   arrived at a erroneous decision to decree the suit in-part against the defendant Nos.1 to 3, (a), 9(b) and 10.<br/> <br/><strong>9.</strong> Finally, Mr. Md. Mamunur Rashid submits that  admittedly a tripartite agreement having been executed between the defendants, Bangladesh Textile Mills Corporation (BTMC) and the  plaintiff in which the defendants admitted the loan liability of the defendant No.1 during the time B.T.M.C. was in the management of the defendant No.1, company and the defendants acknowledged to pay the same with interest and as such,  the finding of the Artharin Adalat in the  language <strong>“</strong><strong>বি,টি,এম,সি, এর ব্যবসহাপনা থাকাকালে কত টাকা ১ নং বিবাদী প্রতিষ্ঠানের নামে ঋণ গ্রহন করা হয় এবং কত পার্সেন্ট সুদে উও্র ঋণ গ্রহন করা হয় ইহা বাদী ব্যাংক প্রমান করিতে পারে নাই।</strong>” is perverse being contrary to law and fact.<br/> <br/><strong>10.</strong> Mr. Habibul Islam Bhuiyan, the learned Advocate, appearing on behalf of the defendant-respondent No.5, on the other hand, supports the impugned judgment,  which was according to him just, correct and proper. He submits that the plaintiff-bank has utterly failed to prove  its claim with regard to the amount of Tk. . 13,99,95,226.00 allegedly transferred from  BTMC and as such, the appeal is liable to be dismissed.<br/> <br/><strong>11.</strong> We have heard the learned Advocates for both the sides and perused the record. Now, only the material question is to be considered in this appeal whether the Artha Rin Adalat committed any wrong or illegality in not giving decree against the loan of B.T.M.C. as well as  interest against C,C (hypo)   and pledge  loan from the date of filing of the suit.<br/> <br/><strong>12.</strong> On scrutiny of the record, it appears that the plaintiff bank claimed  two kinds of loan, that is, one was transferred from BTMC amounting to TK. 13,99,95,226.00  and the loan taken by the defendant-mill after denationalization amounting to TK. 1,18,45,285.50 (CC pledge) and Tk. 1,72,14,40.05 (CC hypo) although with regard to the claim of Tk. 13,99,95,226.00 the plaintiff-appellant did not mention in the plaint on which date and from which bank how much money was taken as loan on what interest while the defendant-respondent No. 1 (mill)  was under the control of BTMC. It further appears that the defendant respondents in their  written statement  categorically stated that the Government has issued 18.04 crore Treasurery Bond in favour of the plaintiff bank against the loan Exhibit-Kha (4),   which was admitted by PW-1 in his evidence.  It also appears from  the memo No. <strong>0/4/nwg-03/16/386(1) </strong><strong>vide-</strong><strong> cÖ`: N/4</strong>,  the Ministry of Textile has decided  to remit the 100% interest of the loan with a condition that the loanee will submit 10% down payment against the loan and accordingly, the defendant-respondent No. 1 submitted the said 10% down payment.<br/> <br/><strong>13.</strong> The learned judge of the Artha Rin Adalat on the facts of the case and on consideration of the legal position  observed:  “এ ছাড়া প্রদঃ ঘ/৪ বস্ত্রমন্ত্রনালয়ের ০/৪/হাম-০৩/১৬/৩৮৬(১) পত্র পর্যালোচনা করিয়া দেখা যায় ১ নং বিবাদী প্রতিষ্ঠানের নামে বি,টি,এম,সি-র ব্যবসহাপনায় থাকাকালে গৃহীত ঋণের সুদ মওকুফ করা হয়। যাহার প্রেক্ষিতে বানিজ্যিক ব্যাংকের যে আর্থিক ক্ষতি হয় তাহার শতকরা ৫০ ভাগ সরকার বহন করে।  উক্ত সিদ্ধান্তর প্রেক্ষিতে ১ নং বিবাদী প্রতিষ্ঠান ও কুষ্টিয়া টেক্মটাইল মিলের ঋণ পুনঃ তপসিলের সুবিধার্থে সরকার ১৮.০৪ কোটি টাকার বন্ড বাদী ব্যাংক বরাবর ইস্যু করে। সরকার কর্তৃক ইস্যুকৃত উও্র বন্ডের যে টাকা বাদী ব্যাংক ১ নং বিবাদী প্রতিষ্ঠানের নামে গৃহীত ঋণের বিপরীতে প্রদত্ত হইয়াছে তাহা দাবীকৃত টাকা হইতে বাদ যাইবেz কিন্তু বাদী ব্যাংক তদমর্মে কোন হিসাব বা কোন প্রতিবেদন দাখিল করে নাই। ফলে, বাদী ব্যাংক বি,টি,এম,সির হিসাবে কত টাকা প্রাপ্য হইবে তাহার সঠিক কোন হিসাব আদালতে উপস্থাপন করে নাই। অত্র মোকদ্দমায় বি,টি,এম,সি-এর ব্যবসহাপনায় থাকাকালে গৃহীত ঋণ ৬৭,৬৯,০০০/- (সাতষটির লক্ষ উনসত্তর হাজার) টাকার বিপরীতে  বিবাদীগনের উপর ১৩,৯৯,৯৫,২২৬/- (তের কোটি নিরানব্বই লক্ষ পঁচানব্বই হাজার দুইতশ ছাত্রিশ) টাকা বাবদ ডিএ্রী প্রদান করা অযৌও্রিক। অত্র ঋণ মওকুফের জন্য সরকারের  বিবেচনাতে আছে এবং বি,টি,এম,সি-র নিয়ন্ত্রনে থাকাকালীন গৃহীত ঋণের টাকা অত্রাকারে অত্র মোকদ্দমার অন্তর্ভুও্র হইলে জটিলতা সৃষ্টি হইবে। সে কারনে বি,টি,এম,সি, গৃহীত ঋনের বিষয়ে অত্র মোকদ্দমায় সিদ্ধান্ত হইল না। তবে বি,টি,এম, সি-র পরিচালনায় থাকা কালে গৃহীত ঋণের পরিমান, পরিশোধীত ঋণের পরিমান, সরকার কর্তৃক বন্ড মাধ্যমে পরিশোধের পর এবং সরকার কর্তৃক সুদ মওকুফের পরও বাদী ব্যাংকের কোন পাওনা থাকিলে সংশ্লিষ্টদের পক্ষভুও্র করিয়া বাদী ব্যাংক যথাযথভাবে উও্র টাকা আদায় করিতে পারিবে।”<br/> <br/><strong>14.</strong> This being purely a finding of fact based on correct evaluation of the facts and materials of the case.<br/> <br/><strong>15.</strong> It is also found  that in this case the plaintiff-bank to prove its claim examined one witness as PW-1, who in his cross-examination stated that: আমি বাদী ব্যাংকে ১৯৮০ সালে যোগদান করি। এই ঋণ মনজুর ও প্রদানের সময় আমি বাদী ব্যাংকে কর্মরত ছিলাম। তখন আমি সিডি অফিসার ছিলাম। বিবাদী কত টাকা ঋণের জন্য আবেদন করে জানি না। কত টাকা মনজুর হয় বলতে পারব না। ১ নং বিবাদী  প্রতিষ্ঠান মাঝে সরকারী করনে ছিল। বি,টি,এম,সি, পরিচালনার সময় ৩ কোটি টাকার উপরে ঋণ নেয়। মুল ঋণ ছিল ৬৭,৬৯,০০০/- টাকা যাহা সুদে ৫ কোটি টাকার উপরে হয়। বি,টি,এম,সি, মুল শাখা ঢাকা হইতে ঋণ নেয়। ঐ ঋণের কাগজপত্র কোথায় আছে মনে নাই। This witness in his cross-examination also stated that: সি, সি, হাইপো খাতে সুদ আসলে কত টাকা ও সি,সি, প্লেজ খাতে কত টাকা দাবী করি মনে নাই। সি, সি, প্নেজ গুদামের বন্দকী সামগ্রি আমাদের নিয়ন্ত্রনে আসে।<br/> <br/><strong>16.</strong> Taking into  consideration of all these aspects of the case,  we are unable to differ with the view taken by  the  Artha Rin Adalat that the plaintiff could not prove by adducing evidence as to what amount was taken by the defendants from  BTMC which reached at the figure of TK. 13,99,95,226/=.<br/> <br/><strong>17.</strong> Now, turning to consider the second point whether the Artha Rin Adalat committed any wrong or illegality in not giving interest against C,C (hypo)   and pledge  loan from the date of filing of the suit, as prayed for.<br/> <br/><strong>18.</strong> On perusal of the record, it appears that the Artha Rin Adalat after a detailed discussion of the attending circumstances borne out by records held that in view of the provision of section 34 of the Code of Civil Procedure the plaintiff-bank is not entitled to get interest pendente lite  against C, C hypo   and pledge  loan. In coming to this conclusion the said Court observed that: “১ নং বিবাদী প্রতিষ্ঠানটি একটি নিস্ক্রিয় শিল্প প্রতিষ্ঠান ও প্রতিষ্ঠানটি  বন্ধ রহিয়াছে । সরকার কর্তৃক গঠিত নিস্ক্রিয়/ রুগ্ন শিল্প প্রতিষ্ঠান বাছাই কমিটি নিস্ক্রিয় ও রুগ্ন শিল্পের বিপরীতে গৃহীত ঋণের ১০০% সুদ মওকুফের সুপারিশ রহিয়াছে । এমতাবস্থায়, দেওয়ানী কার্য্য বিধির ৩৪ ধারা মতে মামলা দাখিলের পর হইতে সি,সি হাইপো ও প্লেজ ঋণের বিপরীতে পুনরায় সুদ আরোপ করা অযৌক্তিক ও ন্যায় বিচারের পরিপন্থি।<br/> <br/><strong>19.</strong> Now, in approaching the controversy it will be profitable to notice the provision contained in section 34 of the Code of Civil Procedure, which is quoted hereunder:<br/> <br/>34.-(1) Where and in so far as a decree is  for the payment of money, the Court may, in the decree, order interest at such rate as the Court deems reasonable to be paid on the principal sum adjudged, from the date of the suit to the date of the decree, in addition to any interest adjudged on such principal sum for any period to the institution of the suit, with further interest at such rate as the Court seems reasonable on the aggregate sum so adjudged, from the date of the decree to the date of payment, or to such earlier date as the Court thinks fit.<br/>(2) Where such a decree is silent with respect to the payment of further interest on such aggregate sum as aforesaid from the date of the decree to the date of payment or other earlier date, the Court shall be deemed to have refused such interest, and a separate suit therefore shall not lie.<br/> <br/><strong>20.</strong> From the provisions of this section, it transpires that the Court is empowered to grant interest from the date of the suit to the date of the decree and then on the full amount which includes the amount claimed on the date of the suit and the interest thereon granted by the Court for the aforesaid period. Further, this section provides for award of interest on the aggregate sum till the date of realization or an earlier date. It also transpires that the decree holder does not have any statutory right to get interest automatically.   Therefore, we find no difficulty whatever in holding that the grant or award of interest pendent lite is purely a matter of statutory power wherein the discretion of the Court is absolute.<br/> <br/><strong>21.</strong> On perusal of the  entire evidence on record,   it is found that  in the instant  case there are evidence enough on record both oral and documentary  to suggest  that the plaintiff-appellant did not care at all to submit any audit report in order to show the exact amount of money that was revealed through the process of audit as per Ext.7, tripartite agreement although   the respondent-defendant company has produced its audit report wherefrom it appears that after making through inquiry the outstanding dues of the defendant company was found to be TK. 24,98,000/= only which was  duly proved as Ext.4(Kha-1).<br/> <br/><strong>22.</strong> Furthermore, in the facts and circumstance of the case the contention as raised by Mr. Md. Mamunur Rashid that as per section 50 Artharin Adalat Ain-2003 no Court can disallow interest which is to be calculated from the date of granting loan up-to the date of filing suit and as per section 50(2) of the Artharin Adalat Ain-2003  the Court is bound to grant interest pendente lite  is plainly misconceived inasmuch as in this case the impugned judgment  was delivered prior to the new Ain being Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 2003 came into force. Therefore, we find no substance in either of the contentions as raised by the learned Advocate for the plaintiff-appellant-bank.<br/> <br/><strong>23.</strong> For the foregoing reasons stated above, both on law and  fact we are of the view that in the facts and circumstance of the case the Artha Rin Adalat committed no wrong in not awarding interest pendente lite  against C,C hypo   and pledge  loan. The learned judge of the Adalat on the facts of the case and on consideration of the legal position rightly decreed the suit in-part. No interference is therefore called for.<br/> <br/><strong>24.</strong> In the result, the appeal is dismissed without any order as to cost.<br/> <br/><strong>25.</strong> Let a copy of this judgment along with the lower Court’s record be sent down at once.<br/> <br/><strong>Ed. </strong></span></div></div></div>
60	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Agrani Bank Ltd. Vs. Kazi Mustafizur Rahman, 1 LNJ (2012) 452</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Case No:</b> Civil Revision No. 07 of 1996 </p><p><b>Judge:</b>  Sheikh Abdul Awal,</p><p><b>Court:</b> High Court Division,,</p><p><b>Advocate:</b> Mr. Md. Kamruzzaman,,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 LNJ (2012) 452</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2012</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Agrani Bank Ltd.</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  Kazi Mustafizur Rahman</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Artha Rin,Ex-parte Decree,</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2012-02-16</p><div style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="font-size:16px">HIGH COURT DIVISION<br/>(Civil Revisional Jurisdiction)<br/> </span></strong></div><table align="center" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="height:115px; width:370px"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align:right; width:143px"><strong>Mr. Sheikh Abdul Awal, J.<br/><br/>			Judgment<br/>			16.02.2012</strong></td><td style="text-align:justify; width:21px"> </td><td style="text-align:justify; width:126px">Agrani Bank Ltd.			<div style="text-align: right;"><em><strong>….Petitioner</strong></em></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>Vs.</strong></div>			Kazi Mustafizur Rahman			<div style="text-align: right;"><em><strong>…Opposite Party</strong></em></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div style="clear: both; text-align: justify;"> </div><div style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) </strong><br/><strong>Order VII, rule 11</strong><br/><strong>Order IX, rule 13</strong><br/><strong>Artha Rin Adalat Act (IV of 1990)</strong><br/><strong>Sections 6 and 7</strong><br/><strong>It appears that under the Ain of 1990, if any party is aggrieved by the ex-parte decree of the Artha Rin Adalat two remedies are available to judgment debtor or aggrieved party. One, a petition under Order IX, rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure and the other, an appeal before the High Court Division. In both the cases deposit of half of the decreetal amount is a positive requirement and mandate. The plaintiff-opposite party without taking the remedies </strong><strong>available to him challenged</strong><strong> the rightness of the judgment and decree in a suit before a Court of ordinary civil jurisdiction. The suit, thus is clearly barred by law justifying rejection of plaint. .</strong><strong>… (14 and 17)</strong><br/> <br/><em>49 DLR(AD)-135, 16 MLR-97, 12 MLR-73, 9 MLR-17, 18 BLD (AD)-268, 56 DLR-695, 8 MLR(AD)-01, 49 DLR (AD) 135, ref. </em><br/> </div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 80px;"><strong>Mr. Md. Kamruzzaman, Advocate          </strong></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 120px;"><em>…For the Petitioner</em></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 80px;"><strong>No one appears</strong></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 120px;"><em>… For the opposite party.</em></div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 80px;"><strong> <br/><em>Civil Revision No. 07 of 1996</em></strong></div><div style="text-align: justify;"> </div><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size:22px"><strong>Judgment</strong></span></div><div style="text-align: justify;"><u><strong>Sheikh Abdul Awal, J. </strong></u><br/> <br/>This Rule was issued calling upon the opposite party to show cause as to why the order dated 28.9.95 passed by the learned Subordinate Judge, 1<sup>st</sup> Court, Barisal in Title Suit No. 30 of 1995 should not be set aside and / or such other or further order or orders passed as to this Court may seem fit and proper.<br/> <br/><strong>2.</strong>         Facts necessary for disposal of the Rule are that the opposite party as sole plaintiff brought the aforesaid suit being Title Suit No. 30 of 1995 in the Court of learned Subordinate Judge, 1<sup>st</sup> Court, Barisal impleading the petitioner-Agrani Bank as defendant praying a decree declaring the  exparte decree passed in Money Suit No. 3 of 1993 by the Artha Rin  Adalat, Barisal is illegal, collusive and not binding upon the plaintiff.<br/> <br/><strong>3.</strong>         The defendant Agrani Bank entered appearance in the Suit and filed an application under Order VII, Rule 11 read with section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure for rejection of the plaint stating that: “অর্থঋণ আদালতের ডিএ্রির বিরুদ্ধে অত্রাদালতের কোন মোকদ্দমা আইনতঃ রক্ষনীয় নহেz অর্থঋণ আদালত আইন, ১৯৯০ দ্বারা উহা সম্পূর্ন বারিত বটেz এতদ্ব্যতীত মোকদ্দমা তামাদি দোষে ও বারিত বটেz”<br/> <br/><strong>4. </strong>        The learned Subordinate Judge, 1<sup>st</sup> Court, Barisal by the impugned Order No. 12 dated 28.9.1995 rejected the application holding that    if the plaintiff’s allegation of non service of summon is correct, his remedy of a separate suit is not barred.<br/> <br/><strong>5.</strong>         Being aggrieved thereby the present defendant-petitioner-Agrani Bank moved this Court and obtained the present Rule.<br/> <br/><strong>6.  </strong>       Mr. Md. Kamruzzaman, the learned Advo-cate appearing for the petitioner Agrani Bank at the very outset upon referring a number of decisions reported in 49 DLR(AD)-135, 16 MLR-97, 12 MLR-73, 9 MLR-17, 18 BLD (AD)-268, 56 DLR-695 and 8 MLR(AD)-01 submits that the proposition of law is by now well settled that no separate suit lies against the judgment and decree or order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat.<br/> <br/><strong>7. </strong>        Drawing my attention to the provision of section 6 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990, Mr. Md. Kamruzzaman submits that the impugned order does not reflect the true position of law and as such the same is liable to be set-aside.<br/> <br/><strong>8. </strong>        No one has entered appearance to oppose the Rule.<br/> <br/><strong>9.</strong>         I have considered the submission of the learned Advocate and perused the Revisional application along with other materials on record. It is found that the plaintiff-opposite party filed Title Suit No.30 of 1995 impleading the petitioner-Agrani Bank for declaration that the exparte decree passed in Money Suit No. 3 of 1993 is collusive, illegal, without jurisdic-tion and not binding upon the plaintiff.<br/> <br/><strong>10.</strong>       Now, the only question calls for consideration in this Rule whether any separate suit lies against the judgment and decree passed by the Artha Rin Adalat. In order to resolve this point certain provisions of law are required to be referred to for having a better view of the dispute in question.<br/> <br/><strong>11.</strong>       In this connection, I feel it proper to quote Order 7 Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure at the outset which reads as follows :- <br/> <br/><strong>12.</strong>       The Plaint shall be rejected in the following cases:-</div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;"><br/>(a)    where it does not disclose a cause of action.<br/>(b)    where the relief claimed is undervalued , and the plaintiff, on being required by the Court to correct the valuation within a time to be fixed by the Court fails to do so:<br/>(c)    where the relief claimed is properly valued but the plaint is written upon insufficient stamp and the plaintiff on being required by the Court  to supply the requisite stamp-paper within a time to be fixed by the Court, fails to do so :<br/>(d)    where the suit appears from the statement in the plaint to be barred by any law.<br/>(Provided that the time fixed by the Court for the correction of the valuation or supplying of the requisite stamp paper shall not exceed twenty one days ).</div><div style="text-align: justify;"> <br/><strong>13.</strong>       From a plain reading of the aforesaid provision of law, I find that Clause (d) of Rule 11 of Order 7 is relevant for our purpose. Since, the defendant claims that the said suit is barred under the specific provision of law as contemplated under section 6 of Artha Rin Adalat Ain,1990. Therefore, I also feel it necessary to quote the aforesaid provisions of law. Section 6 of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990 reads as follows :-</div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;"><br/>“৬। অর্থ ঋণ আদালতের সিদ্ধামত্ম চুড়ামত্ম। (১) ধারা ৭ এর বিধান সাপেক্ষে, অর্থ ঋণ আদালতের কার্য্যধারা, আদেশ, রায় ও ডিক্রী সম্পর্কে কোন আদালত বা অন্য কোন কর্তৃপক্ষের নিকট প্রশ্ন উত্থাপন করা যাইবে না।‘<br/>(২) উপ-ধারা (১) এ যাহা কিছুই থাকুক না কেন, কোন অর্থ ঋণ আদালত কর্তৃক বিবাদীর বিরুদ্ধে প্রদত্ত কোন একতরফা ডিক্রী রদ করার জন্য বিবাদী Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (Act V of 1903) এর Order IX Gi rule 13 এর বিধান মোতাবেক আদালতে দরখাসত্ম করিতে চাহিলে তাহাকে তাহার বিরুদ্ধে ডিক্রীকৃত অর্থের অমত্মতঃ অর্ধেক অর্থ বা উহার সমপরিমান অর্থের ব্যাংক জামানত দরখাসেত্মর সহিত আদালতে জমা করিতে হইবে, এবং উক্তরুপ জমা করা না হইলে তাহার দরখাসত্ম গ্রহন যোগ্য হইবে না।”</div><div style="text-align: justify;"> <br/><strong>14.</strong>       From a plain reading of the above quoted provisions of the Artha Rin Adalat Ain, 1990, it appears that under the Ain of 1990, if any party is aggrieved by the ex-parte decree of the Artha Rin Adalat two remedies are available to judgment debtor or aggrieved party. One, a petition under Order IX, rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure and the other, an appeal before the High Court Division. In both the cases deposit of half of the decreetal amount is a positive requirement and mandate.<br/> <br/><strong>15.</strong>       In this connection I must quote a passage from a case of Nur Islam (Md) Vs Agroni Bank reported in 49 DLR (AD) 135 for having a better view in the dispute in question which reads as follows:</div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;"><br/>Mr. AKM Nurun Nabi Khan, learned Advocate appearing for the petitioner, contends that <u>when the petitioner-defendant challenged the exparte decree on the ground of fraud his application under section 151 CPC is quite maintainable. We do not find any substance in this contention, for the Artha Rin Adalat Act specifically provides for only two remedies against an exparte decree</u>. It is either by an application or by an appeal; but in both the cases deposit of 50% of decretal amount is necessary. To avoid this deposit, it appears, the petitioner has sought a short-cut by invoking section 151 CPC which is not applicable in such a situation. The application under section 151 is found to have been rightly dismissed.</div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;">(The under linings are mine)</div><div style="text-align: justify;"> <br/><strong>16.</strong>       In the case  being M. Tariqullah Sikder Vs. Sonali Bank reported in 56 DLR(2007)695 also provides similar feature to the effect that provision of Section 6 of the Artha Rin Adalat  Ain 1990 bars instituting of separate suit to set aside exparte decree passed by Artha Rin Adalat. Only available  scope for setting aside ex-parte  decree passed by Artha Rin Adalat in Artha Rin case is to file miscellaneous case under Order IX  rule 13 of the Code of Civil Procedure  by deposit of 50% of decreetal amount or in the alternative in the appeal as contemplated under the said Ain.<br/> <br/><strong>17.</strong>       As, I have already noticed that in this case the plaintiff-opposite party without taking the remedies available to him challenged the rightness of the judgment and decree in a suit before a Court of ordinary civil jurisdiction. The suit, thus is clearly barred by law justifying rejection of plaint.<br/> <br/><strong>18.</strong>       For the reasons stated above, I am inclined to hold that the learned Assistant Judge seriously erred in law in passing the impugned order without properly applying his judicial mind into the facts and circumstances of the case and law bearing on the subject and the same has resulted in an error in the impugned decision occasioning failure of justice.<br/> <br/><strong>19.</strong>       In the result, the Rule is made absolute. The impugned order dated 28.9.95 passed by the learned Subordinate Judge, 1<sup>st</sup> Court, Barisal in Title Suit No. 30 of 1995 refusing to reject plaint stands set-aside. Plaint of Title Suit No. 30 of 1995 of the said Court stands rejected.<br/> <br/><strong>20.</strong>       The order of stay granted earlier by this Court so far it relates to Execution Case No. 19 of 1994 arising out of Money Suit No. 03 of 1993 pending in the 1<sup>st</sup> Court of learned Subordinate Judge, and Artha Rin Adalat, Barisal stands vacated.<br/> </div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;">The Artha Rin Adalat concerned is directed to proceed with the Money Execution Case No. 19 of 1994 arising out of Money Suit No. 03 of 1993 expeditiously.</div><div style="text-align: justify;"> </div><div style="text-align: justify; margin-left: 40px;"><strong>Ed.</strong></div></div></div>
61	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Ahamadur Rahman Chowdhury Vs. Standard Bank Ltd. &amp; ors., (Syed Md. Ziaul Karim, J.) </h2>

Zakir Hossain, J. </p><p><b>Court:</b> High Court Division,</p><p><b>Advocate:</b> Mr. Abdul Halim Kafi, Advocate, with Mr. Khaled Mahmud Saifulla, Advocate, Mrs. Khurshed Jahan, Advocate,  Mr. Shahidul Islam, D.A.G. with Mr. Md. Jahangir Alam, A.A.G. Mr. Kalipada Mridha, A.A.G. and Mr. Mehadi Hasan, A.A.G.,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2019(1) LNJ </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2018</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Ahamadur Rahman Chowdhury  </p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  Standard Bank Ltd. and six others, Bangladesh Bank, represented by its Governor, Main Office, Motijheel Commercial Area, Police Station-Motijheel, Dhaka. </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Bangladesh Labour Code </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2019-11-26</p><!DOCTYPE html><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">HIGH COURT DIVISION</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">(CIVIL REVISIONAL JURISDICTION)</span></strong></span></p><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="MsoNormalTable" style="margin-left: 5.4pt; border-collapse: collapse; mso-yfti-tbllook: 480; mso-padding-alt: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;"><tbody><tr style="mso-yfti-irow: 0; mso-yfti-firstrow: yes; mso-yfti-lastrow: yes;"><td style="width: 106.0pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;" valign="top" width="141"><p class="MsoHeading8" style="margin: 0in -1.4pt 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold', serif; letter-spacing: -0.3pt; font-style: normal;">Syed Md. color: #000000;">}</span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: center; margin: 0in -1.1pt 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: #000000;">}</span></p></td><td style="width: 94.05pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;" width="125"><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: #000000;">Ahamadur Rahman Chowdhury </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 10pt;">. . . Plaintiff-Applicant</span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: #000000;">Standard Bank Ltd. and six others</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 10pt;">. . .Defendant </span></em></strong><strong><em><span style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold', serif; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Respondent Nos. 1-7</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">Bangladesh Bank, represented by its Governor, Main Office, Motijheel Commercial Area, Police Station-Motijheel, Dhaka.</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Proforma defendant Respondent No.8.</span></em></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.25pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Bangladesh Labour Code (XLII of 2006)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Sections 2(49) and 2(65)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Going through the appointment letter of the plaintiff and his dismissal order, it appears that the employee (Plaintiff) was terminated with stigma. It is well settled that plaintiff an employee, when terminated with stigma and for removing the stigma suit is maintainable, even the service condition is governed by master and servant rule. From the plain reading of the provisions of Sections 2(49) and 2(65) of the Bangladesh Labour Code, 2006, we find that responsibilities of plaintiff was administrative or management of the duties. So, the relationship between the employer (Bank) and employee (plaintiff) were not governed by Master and servant rule.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">         </span>. . . (10 and 12)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 151</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Order VII, Rule 11</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The plaint of a suit can be rejected by exercising the Power under section 151 of </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold', serif; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">the Code, when from plain reading of the plaint;</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> it appears that the suit is barred under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code.<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">  </span>. . . (13)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Order VII, Rule 11(d)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Clause (d) of the Rule 11 of Order VII authorize the rejection of a plaint when the suit appears from the statements in the plaint to be barred by any law. This clause applies when it appear from the statements in the plaint that the suit is barred but it has no application where there is no clear or specific admission in the plaint suggesting that the suit is barred. This clause is attracted only when on the admitted facts as appearing from the plaint itself the suit is prima facie barred. As for instance when from the statements made in the plaint it appears that the cause of action arose beyond the period of limitation fixed under the statue and no indication is given that limitation has been saved, the plaint may be rejected. In a proper case, when it appears to be barred by limitation, the plaint may be allowed to be amended without rejection. It is not mandatory for the Court to reject the plaint. It may ask the plaintiff to amend it so as to make suit maintainable. Where the plaintiff does not comply with such an order the Court may reject the plaint. In the instant case, there is nothing on record to show that on the admitted facts as appearing from the plaint itself the suit is prima facie barred. So the rule 11(d) is not at all attracted here and the plaint cannot be rejected on that score. All the facts and submissions of the learned Counsel of both the parties indicate that the plaint of the suit should not be rejected by exercising the Power laid down in section 151 of the Code by taking the recourse of Order VII Rule 11 (d) of the Code.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>In view of the above, the Court below without considering the materials on record and aforesaid principles of law, by rejecting the plaint of the suit committed an error of law. Therefore, the impugned judgment and decree of the Court below is liable to be interfered by the High </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold', serif; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Court Division. The impugned judgment and</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> decree is set aside. The suit will proceed in </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 'Times New Roman Bold', serif; letter-spacing: -0.1pt;">accordance with law. <span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">                                 </span>...(16, 19, 26, 27 and 29)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 109%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">Aftabuddin Ahmed, Executive Director, UCEP, Dhaka Vs. Md. Shamsul Alom and others 2 Apex Law Report (ALR) 348; Managing Director, Janata Bank Vs. Hafijuddin Ahmed and others 29 DLR (SC) 39; Bangladesh Commerce Bank Ltd. and another Vs. Md. Nasir- uz- Zaman 19 BLR 71;<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Jahir Uddin (Md.) Vs. Rupali Bank Ltd. and others 12 BLC (AD) 114; International Finance Investment and Commerce Bank Liimited Vs. Mr. Abdul Quayum and another 19 BLD (AD) 234; Ratan Chand Dharam Chand Vs. The Secretary of State for India in Council and another 18 CWN 1340; Maqsood Ali Vs. Deputy Commissioner, Bara Banki and another AIR 1928, Oudh, 495; Sreedam Chandra Bhur Vs. Tencori Mukherjee and others A.I.R 1953 Cal. 222; Gunnaji Bhavaji Vs. Makanji Khoosal Chand 34 Bom 250; Prankrishna Vs. Kripannath 21 Cal. WN 209; Sundar Ali being dead his heirs: Mannan and others Vs. Md.Serajul Islam Sarker and others 56 DLR (AD) 210; Abdul Malek Sawdagar Vs. Md. Mahbubey Alam and others 57 DLR (AD) 18; Md. Abul Khair Vs. Pubali Bank Ltd. and another 21 BLD (AD) 32=53 DLR (AD) 62; Afzal Hossain Diptee Vs. Radha Kanta Korati and others 15 BLC 196; Bangladesh Water Development Board Vs. Contractor Manu Barrage 9 BLT 21 and Shafi A. Chowdhury Vs. Pubali Bank Ltd. and others 54 DLR 310 ref.<u></u></span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">Mr. Abdul Halim Kafi, Advocate, with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: #000000;">Mr. Khaled Mahmud Saifulla, Advocate, </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . . For the plaintiff-appellant,</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: #000000;">Mrs. Khurshed Jahan, Advocate, </span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . . For the respondent Nos. 1-7</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">Mr. Shahidul Islam, D.A.G. with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">Mr. Md. Jahangir Alam, A.A.G.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">Mr. Kalipada Mridha, A.A.G. and</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">Mr. Mehadi Hasan, A.A.G.</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . . For the proforma defendant respondent No. 8. </span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Syed Md. Ziaul Karim, J:</span></u></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">By this appeal, the plaintiff appellant has challenged the legality and propriety of the judgment and decree dated 25-02-2015 passed by learned Joint District Judge, Fifth Court, Dhaka, rejecting the plaint of Title Suit no. 18 of 2015 under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure(briefly as the Code).</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">2.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Materials facts leading to this appeal are that on 19-01-2015 the appellant as plaintiff<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>instituted Title Suit no. 18 of 2015 in the fifth Court of Joint District Judge, Dhaka impleading the respondents as defendants for declaration that the order of dismissal dated 30-11-2014 passed by defendant no.2, terminating him from the post of Senior Vice President and Regional Manager is illegal, inoperative and still he is in service and also for realization of outstanding arear salary for Tk.10,25,015/-along with interest. The relieves claimed in suit reads as hereunder:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: .75in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“</span></em></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">L)<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>h¡c£l fË¡bÑ£a j­a, 2ew ¢hh¡c£ LaÑªL ü¡r¢la ¢hNa 30-11-2014 Cw a¡¢l­Ml h¡c£­L Q¡L¥l£ qC­a hlM¡­Øal ¢Q¢W h¡¢am, ®h-BCe£, AL¡kÑLl Hhw h¡c£ HM­e¡ Q¡L¤l£­a ü­ha­e<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>hq¡m B­R j­jÑ HL ¢XH²£<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>fËc¡e L¢l­a ;</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: .75in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">M)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">          </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">h¡c£ ¢hh¡c£N­Zl ¢eLV ®hae h¡hc h­Lu¡ 10,25,015/-(cn mr Q¢õn q¡S¡l) V¡L¡ fËc¡­el<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Hhw j¡jm¡ c¡­u­ll a¡¢lM qC­a 18% h¡¢oÑL q¡­l p¤cpq r¢af§lZ f¡Ju¡l qLc¡l j­jÑ HL ®O¡oZ¡j§mL ¢XH²£ ¢c­a;</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: .75in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">N)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">           </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">e¡¢m­nl pjÉL hÉu h¡c£l Ae¤L¥­m Hhw ¢hh¡c£N­el fË¢aL¥­m ¢XH²£ ¢c­a;</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: .75in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">O)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">           </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">h¡c£ Bq~e J CL¥C¢Vj­a Bl ®k ®k fË¢aL¡l f¡C­a f¡­l ®p j­jÑ h¡c£l Ae¤L¥­m ¢XH²£ ¢c­a z</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">3.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Later the suit was fixed for hearing over the maintainability matter. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">4.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt;">After hearing the learned Judge by the impugned judgment and decree dated 25-02-2015 rejected the plaint of the suit under section 151 of the Code holding that the employer and employee of the Bank based on Doctrine of master and servant Rule, so the legal right of the plaintiff has not been infringed. So the suit is not maintainable. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">5.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The learned Advocate appearing for the appellant seeks to impeach the impugned judgment and decree on two fold arguments:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.35pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><u><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Firstly:</span></u></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The plaintiff instituted the suit challenging his dismissal order and also for recovery for realization of his outstanding salary. So the civil court has the ample jurisdiction to try such suit;</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Secondly:</span></u></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The plaint of the suit clearly disclosed the cause of action and from plain reading of the plaint it is not found that the suit is barred under law. Moreso, the learned Judge of the Court below most erroneously applied the principle of doctrine of master and servant Rule in this suit, thereby committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">6.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In support of his contentions he refers the following decisions:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l1 level1 lfo2; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">1.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">       </span></span></span><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the case of Aftabuddin Ahmed, Executive Director, UCEP, Dhaka vs. Md. Shamsul Alom and others 2 Apex Law repot (ALR) 348 held :</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">      </span>“ Specific Relief Act, 1877</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">      </span>Section 42- Want of prayer for consequential relief when not fatal for a suit ?</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">      </span>On plain reading of the prayer portion of the plaint together with the contents of the plaint, it is evident that the prayer of the plaintiff for relief is complete and exhaustive and as such there is no scope to hold that the suit is bad for want of necessary consequential relief.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">      </span>Doctrine of Master and Servant rule.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">      </span>When the conditions of service of the plaintiff are regulated by the provisions of Chapter 7 of UCEP Service Rules, 2004, there is no scope to hold that the doctrine of Master and Servant has any manner of application in the case.”</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; mso-list: l1 level1 lfo2; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">2.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></em><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the case of Managing Director, Janata Bank vs. Hafijuddin Ahmed and others 29 DLR(SC) 39 held:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">   </span>“Service- Dismissal from service-Employee of a statutory corporation.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">   </span>Employee of a statutory corporation cannot be placed in the category of relationship subsisting between master and servant and therefore before his dismissal from service of the corporation he is entitled to a show-cause notice-Such employee does not acquire the status of government of public servant. </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">   </span>An employee of a statutory corporations does not come within the Master and Servant rule and is entitled to show cause notice before his dismissal, whether there is any statutory justice rule or not, and also because of the cumulative effect of diverse legislature enactments his service has a public character.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>The respondent no.1 is therefore, entitled to a legal character and can maintain a suit for declaration under section 42 of the Specific Relief Act.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">   </span>The finding of the learned Judge that the employee of a statutory corporation because of various legislative measures has become a government servant or public servant entitled to the benefits of the constitutional safeguards cannot be substained from the reasons set out in Civil Appeal no. 9 of 1975.”</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; mso-list: l1 level1 lfo2; tab-stops: list 59.25pt left 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">3.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">    </span></span></span><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the case of Bangladesh Commerce Bank Ltd. and another vs. Md. Nasir-uz-Zaman 19 BLC 71 held:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">“ Code of Civil Procedure</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.35pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Order VII, rule 11(d)</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.35pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Bangladesh Bank Order(P.O. 128 of 1972)</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Article 34(5)</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">An employee, when terminated with stigma and for removing the stigma suit is maintainable even the service condition is governed by master and servant rule.”</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l1 level1 lfo2; tab-stops: list 59.25pt left 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">4.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">    </span></span></span><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the case of Jahir Uddin (Md.) vs. Rupali Bank Ltd. and others 12 BLC(AD) 114 held:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: #000000;">“<em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"> Specific Relief Act (1 of 1877)</em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sections 42, 55 and 56</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">As it appears the High Court Division made the Rule absolute holding that admittedly on and from 06-04-1984 the defendant bank, being denatinalised, was converted into a private bank incorporated under the Companies Act, 1994 and, as such, the relationship between the plaintiff-petitioner and the defendant bank became that of master and servant from that date and therefore, the petitioner is not entitled to get a decree for declaration without consequential relief; in the instant case there is no prayer for mandatory injunction for consequential relief, even if there is a prayer for mandatory injunction but that that too cannot be granted in view of legal bar under clause (e) of section 56 of the Specific Relief Act which provides that an order of mandatory injunction cannot be granted to prevent the breach of a contract the performance of which could not be specifically enforced; the breach of contract for personal service cannot be restrained by court ordering an employer to retain the employee in the service as it is the prerogative right of the employer to discharge his vlations the suit is not maintainable as the plaintiff challenged the order of<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>suspension and the final show cause notice but<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>did not challenge the order of dismissal in which the impugned order of suspension and show cause merged and with the order of dismissal the orders of suspension and final show cause became infructuous and in the instant case this issue, which cuts the case at its root, has not been considered at all by the appellate Court below.”</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; mso-list: l1 level1 lfo2; tab-stops: list 59.25pt left 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">5.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">    </span></span></span></em><!--[endif]--><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the case of International Finance Investment and Commerce Bank Limited vs. Mr. Abdul Quayum and another 19 BLD(AD) 234 held:</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.35pt; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">“ Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.35pt; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 561A </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.35pt; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Penal Code, 1860</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.35pt; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 21</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.35pt; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Bank Companies Act, 1991</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 27.35pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.35pt; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 1.0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Section-110.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 9.0pt; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 1.0in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The accused who was a Manager of the IFIC Bank and the complainant who is an officer of the Bank are public servants as it is a Banking company whose 40%<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>shares are held by the Government of the People’s Republic of Bangladesh. So both the complainant and the accused are public servants and the complaint has been filed before the Senior Special Judge and Sessions Judge, Dhaka, for taking cognizance under section 409, 477(A) and 462(A) of the Penal Code and under section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 for<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>misappropriating an amount of Tk.26.18 crores causing huge loss to the Bank. Section 110 of Bank Companies Act, 1991 also provides that a Manager, Officer and other functionaries of the banking company are deemed to be public servants under section 21 of the Penal Code. Thus, by reference to the relevant law it appears that the appellant and the respondents are public servants and the case has been rightly instituted in the Court of Special Judge against the <span style="letter-spacing: -.3pt;">respondent who is also a public servant.”</span></span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">7.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The learned Advocates appearing for the defendant nos. 1-7 and 8 oppose the appeal and submits that the learned Judge of the Court below after considering the law and facts and by relying the case reported in 12 BLC(AD) 114 rightly held that relationship between the Employer (Bank) and Employee (Plaintiff) are master and servant. So rightly rejected the plaint of the suit which calls for no interference by this Court.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">8.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In order to appreciate their submissions we have gone through the records and given <span style="letter-spacing: -.3pt;">our anxious considerations to their submissions.</span> </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">9.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">             </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Now the points for consideration whether the impugned judgment and decree calls for interference by this Court.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">10.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">On going to the material on records it transpires that the plaintiff instituted the suit for declaration that his dismissal order dated 30-11-2014<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">    </span>issued by the defendant no. 2 is illegal, void, inoperative and still he is in service and also for realization of his outstanding arear salary for Tk. 10,25,015/- with interest. It is pertinent to point out that the plaintiff was the Senior Vice-President and regional Manager of Standard Bank Ltd. and the letter of dismissal was issued by the Managing Director of the said Bank. The learned Judge relied the decision reported in 12 BLC (AD)114 and held that relationship between the employer and employee of that Bank are the master and servant relationship. So the legal right of the plaintiff has not been infringed. We have carefully gone through the above decisions and find that the same is absolutely distinguishable to that of the instant case. In the said case the plaintiff challenged the order of suspension, not the final order, but in the instant case the plaintiff challenged the order of dismissal itself. Moreso, we have gone through the appointment letter of the plaintiff and his dismissal order, wherein we find that the employee (Plaintiff) was terminated with stigma. It is well settled that plaintiff an employee, when terminated with stigma and for removing the stigma suit is maintainable, even the service condition is governed by master and servant rule. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l2 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list 0in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">11.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">         </span></span></span></strong><!--[endif]--><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sections 2(49) and 2(65) of the Bangladesh Labour Code 2006 provides the definition of </span><strong><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">j¡¢mL</span></em></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(Master) and<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span></span><strong><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">nË¢jL</span></em></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>(servant) which read as hereunder:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“2(49)</span></em></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"> ®L¡e fË¢aù¡e pÇjf­LÑ, <span style="mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;">j¡¢mL</span> AbÑ Hje ®L¡e hÉ¢J² ¢k¢e fË¢aù¡­e nË¢jL ¢e­u¡N L­le, Hhw ¢ejÀ¢m¢Ma hÉ¢J²NZJ Cq¡l A¿¹iÑ§J²<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>qC­he, kb¡-</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l1 level2 lfo2; tab-stops: 27.0pt 45.0pt list 104.25pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="color: #000000;"><!-- [if !supportLists]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">L)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">       </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">M)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">    </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">N)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">     </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">O)<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">     </span></span></span></em></strong><!--[endif]--><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;
